item.title: North Korean Soldiers Return From Russia’s War With Ukraine
item.description: Kim Jong-un hugged the returning troops and awarded the country’s highest medal to nine soldiers killed in action.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

media:content.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, hugs a soldier in Pyongyang during a ceremony welcoming troops home from a deployment in Russia’s Kursk region, in a photograph released by state media.

item.title: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Fee Faces Lawsuit
item.description: California and New York are among the states arguing that the Trump administration’s decision to charge that fee for skilled foreign workers is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump after signing a proclamation instituting the visa fee for some foreign workers in September.

item.title: Los ataques a embarcaciones en el Caribe podrían resultar en ‘daños morales’ para los militares
item.description: Los soldados que participan en misiones que consideran equivocadas o injustificadas pueden sufrir un profundo daño psicológico, según investigaciones.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Cada ataque mortal implica a numerosos militares que pueden correr el riesgo de sufrir daños psicológicos.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 13, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 13, 2025.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 14, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: For Ukrainians, U.S. Talks Are Just Background Din to Blackouts
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 13, 2025.

item.title: Judge’s Order Complicates Justice Dept. Plans to Again Charge Comey
item.description: Justice Department officials have been considering whether to bring new charges against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, after a different judge dismissed the original case against him.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Monica Jorge for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A judge’s order suggested that sloppiness by the Justice Department had helped to sabotage President Trump’s demands to use the criminal justice system to go after James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.

item.title: Government Can Withhold Funds From Planned Parenthood, Appeals Court Rules
item.description: A three-judge panel threw out a lower court’s order, allowing the Trump administration to continue defunding the group and other major abortion providers.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Planned Parenthood has said that if allowed to take effect, the provision could lead to closures of the organization’s health clinics and decimate its budget.

item.title: Board of Creatives?
item.description: Gene Louise De Vera’s puzzle sets a record!
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Marco Bertorello/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A snorkeler facing a school of tropical fish at a zoo in Italy.

item.title: Así fue el osado escape de María Corina Machado de Venezuela a Oslo
item.description: Veteranos de guerra extrajeron a la política de Venezuela, evadiendo oleajes y mares altamente peligrosos bajo vigilancia estadounidense.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero

media:content.media:credit: Leonhard Foeger/Reuters
media:content.media:description: María Corina Machado pasó el último año escondiéndose del régimen del presidente Nicolás Maduro de Venezuela.

item.title: U.S. Boarded Ship and Seized Cargo Heading to Iran From China
item.description: The seizure last month came amid fears of a renewed conflict between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Eric Schmitt

media:content.media:credit: Tingshu Wang/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Yantian port in Shenzhen, China. The United States had been tracking cargo as it made its way from China to Iran.

item.title: Las autoridades de migración de EE. UU. usan datos de vuelos para las deportaciones
item.description: La Administración de Seguridad en el Transporte ahora comparte listas de pasajeros con el Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas para identificar y detener a los viajeros sujetos a órdenes de deportación.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times

item.title: El oficial que supervisó los ataques de EE. UU. frente a Venezuela se retira
item.description: El almirante Alvin Halsey había anunciado abruptamente que dejaría su cargo de jefe del Mando Sur. Su salida deja sin respuesta varias cuestiones sobre las ofensivas.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Rebecca Blackwell/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: El almirante Alvin Holsey se convirtió en el más reciente de una serie de al menos una veintena de líderes militares, muchos de ellos personas de color y mujeres, que han dejado sus puestos este año.

item.title: Venezuela Oil Tanker Seized by U.S. Was Part of Effort to Finance Cuba
item.description: Firms with ties to Cuba are getting a larger share of Venezuelan oil exports, as the island’s security agents boost President Nicolás Maduro’s defenses.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Nicholas Nehamas and Farnaz Fassihi

media:content.media:credit: Vantor, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: An oil tanker called the Skipper in the southern Caribbean Sea. It was seized by the United States.

item.title: House G.O.P. Releases Health Plan That Would Allow Subsidies to End
item.description: The legislation, expected to come to a vote next week, would make changes that could eventually affect health care costs but are unlikely to immediately curb rising premiums.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: After False Earthquake Alert in Nevada, Lawmakers Demand Answers on How it Was Sent
item.description: The federal government and earthquake experts blamed a technical glitch for the alert that sent warnings hundreds of miles away last week.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

media:content.media:credit: Emily Najera for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The outskirts of Reno, Nev. Last week an early warning system set off a false alarm for an earthquake nearby.

item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX Valued at $800 Billion, as It Prepares to Go Public
item.description: A sale of insider shares at $421 a share would make Mr. Musk’s rocket company the most valuable private company in the world, as it readies for a possible initial public offering next year.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The SpaceX launchpad in South Texas in June 2024. The company said in a letter to employees on Friday that it could go public in 2026.

item.title: Behind the Venezuelan Opposition Leader’s Daring Escape to Oslo
item.description: An American firm with experience in special operations spirited María Corina Machado, the recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, out of the country in a secretive land, sea and air operation.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero

media:content.media:credit: Leonhard Foeger/Reuters
media:content.media:description: María Corina Machado spent the last year hiding from President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela’s regime.

item.title: National Guardsman Who Was Shot in D.C. Making ‘Extraordinary Progress,’ Doctor Says
item.description: Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, who suffered a head wound in the shooting near the White House last month, has moved from acute care to rehabilitation.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial in honor of Specialist Sarah Beckstrom and Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe in Washington.

item.title: Risk-Based Screening Works as Well as Yearly Checks After 40 in Finding Breast Cancers
item.description: A study of more than 45,000 women found that screening women according to their level of risk was as effective in detecting tumors as the one-size-fits-most screening currently recommended.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

media:content.media:credit: Marcelo Del Pozo/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A breast cancer awareness event in Seville, Spain, in October.

item.title: U.S. Lifts Sanctions Against Justice Alexandre de Moraes of Brazil
item.description: A senior Trump administration official said that maintaining sanctions against Justice Alexandre de Moraes was no longer in the interest of the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Justice Alexandre de Moraes reading the charges against former President Jair Bolsonaro during the opening session of the trial in Brazil in September.

item.title: Trump Faces Same Demons as Biden: Age, Health and the Economy
item.description: Too old? Tough economy? The presidents change, but the troubles are familiar.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump has recently faced questions about his health and handling of the economy.

item.title: Deadly Storm Causes Massive Flooding Across Gaza
item.description: Nearly 795,000 displaced people in Gaza were at risk of dangerous floodwaters, according to the United Nations. The heavy rain and strong winds flooded makeshift shelters and collapsed several buildings, according to the Gaza Civil Defense.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga, Nader Ibrahim and Saher Alghorra

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Officials Sue to Seize 2020 Ballots in a Georgia County
item.description: The Justice Department escalated an effort to seize and inspect old ballots in Fulton County, where President Trump was booked in his criminal election interference case.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Election workers during the Fulton County ballot recount in Atlanta in November 2020.

item.title: Rescuers Work to Evacuate Flooded Areas of Washington
item.description: Also, T.S.A. is giving passenger data to immigration agents. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rescue crews in Burlington, Wash., on Friday.

item.title: For Republicans, Trump’s Hands-Off Approach to Health Care Is a Problem
item.description: The prospect of soaring health care costs could exacerbate Americans’ feelings about affordability, an issue that President Trump has tried to downplay. But Democrats plan to keep the issue front and center.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said Thursday night that he may soon start negotiating with Democrats to lower health care costs.

item.title: In Florida’s Panhandle, a Hearing on School Vaccine Mandates Gets Heated
item.description: The hearing was the first concrete step toward repealing some of the state’s vaccine requirements. Rolling back others would require legislative action.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Brendan Farrington

media:content.media:credit: Kate Payne/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Larry Downs Jr. speaks against childhood vaccine mandates at a public hearing held by Florida’s Department of Health on Friday in Panama City Beach, Fla.

item.title: Stream These 10 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in January
item.description: A ton of titles are expiring soon for U.S. subscribers. Catch them while you can, including a Scorsese classic and one of TV’s most influential series.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: F.D.A. Approves Two New Drugs to Treat Gonorrhea
item.description: The sexually transmitted disease has become increasingly resistant to existing antibiotics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs

media:content.media:credit: Science Photo Library/Science Source
media:content.media:description: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium that causes gonorrhea.

item.title: For Rubio the Cuba Hawk, the Road to Havana Runs Through Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s secretary of state and national security adviser has long sought to cripple or topple Cuba’s government, which has close security and economic ties to Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s parents immigrated to Florida from Havana three years before Cuba’s communist revolution prevailed in 1959.

item.title: Amid Fractures on the Right, Tucker Carlson Continues His Attacks
item.description: On Theo Von’s show this week, Mr. Carlson lashed out at a major supporter of the president, the F.B.I. and “unimpressive, dumb, totally noncreative people” leading the nation.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley

media:content.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Tucker Carlson did not mention President Trump by name in his attacks on Theo Von’s podcast, but his broadsides were the latest evidence of a deepening divide in Republican politics.

item.title: Cauliflower Piccata
item.description: Piccata sauce — that buttery, briny combination of lemon, butter and capers, silky in texture and tart in flavor — is not just for chicken or swordfish.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Cooking

item.title: Penne al Baffo (Creamy Tomato-Ham Pasta)
item.description: “Al Baffo” is said to be the abbreviated version of an Italian expression “da leccarsi i baffi,” which translates to “it is so good you’ll lick your whiskers,” because the sauce is abundant, thick and creamy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Cooking

item.title: Phil Upchurch, Jazz Guitarist and Sideman to Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: A self-taught session man extraordinaire, he played with a constellation of stars, including Michael Jackson, Curtis Mayfield, Chaka Khan and Dizzy Gillespie.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:credit: Frans Schellekens/Redferns via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Phil Upchurch in 1983, playing at the North Sea Jazz Festival in The Hague. Although he was known for his versatility across multiple genres, he considered himself a jazz player — albeit one with his own vision.

item.title: Canadians Rush to Buy Stockpiles of Boycotted U.S. Liquor
item.description: Four Canadian provinces are selling off the American liquor they pulled from shelves in protest over President Trump’s tariffs. Some bourbon drinkers are thrilled.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Arlyn McAdorey/Reuters
media:content.media:description: American alcohol products were removed from store shelves in much of Canada when U.S. tariffs against the country went into effect in March.

item.title: Scenes From Washington After a Week of Torrential Rain and Flooding
item.description: More than 100,000 residents were told to leave their homes across Washington State this week as rivers overflowed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rescue crews from Spokane combed through floodwaters near SR-20 in Burlington, Wash., on Friday.

item.title: King Charles Relays ‘Good News’ About His Cancer Treatment
item.description: In a recorded message aired on Friday, King Charles III said that his doctors planned to scale back his cancer treatment starting next year, after being diagnosed in early 2024. The monarch also promoted cancer research and screening programs for early detection.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Tommy Forbes/Bango Studios, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: King Charles III appearing in a prerecorded video released on Friday as part of a cancer awareness program.

item.title: The Best Coffee Tables, at a Range of Prices
item.description: Low-to-the-ground styles to hold in high esteem, no matter the price point.
item.dc:creator: Tom Delavan

item.title: National Parks Ordered to Remove Items Promoting D.E.I. From Gift Shops
item.description: The Interior Department said that the review of retail items would ensure gift shops at national parks did not “promote specific viewpoints.”
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Zion Canyon Visitor Center at Zion National Park in Utah in August.

item.title: In a Hamlet Built on Forbidden Love, a Cyclone Buried It All
item.description: Three generations of a family built their homes and lives in Sri Lanka’s highland tea country. The biggest storm in decades wiped out their hamlet in a landslide.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Pamodi Waravita and Atul Loke

media:content.media:description: Villagers carrying bodies for burial at a cemetery in Kandy in Sri Lanka.

item.title: Cyclone Aftermath in Sri Lanka
item.description: Mujib Mashal, our South Asia bureau chief, takes us to Kandy in Sri Lanka, which suffered the worst of the devastation from last month’s cyclone.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Laura Salaberry and Atul Loke

item.title: T.S.A. Is Providing Air Passenger Data to Immigration Agents for Deportation Effort
item.description: The Transportation Security Administration is providing passenger lists to Immigrations and Customs Enforcement to identify and detain travelers subject to deportation orders.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times

item.title: In Trump’s Justice Dept., Failing in Court Might Be Better Than Bucking the Boss
item.description: Thursday demonstrated an emerging reality for President Trump: Commanding the Justice Department is not the same as controlling the justice system.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The White House was served a legal rebuke this week when federal grand jurors in Alexandria, Va., rejected the Justice Department’s push to indict Letitia James, the New York attorney general, on mortgage-related charges for the second time in a week.

item.title: Harvard Replaces Leader of Health Center Said to Have Focused on Palestinians
item.description: The center at the university’s public health school was also a focus of the Trump administration after having been examined in a Harvard antisemitism report earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The François-Xavier Bagnoud Center for Health and Human Rights at Harvard’s public health school will have new leadership. An interim was named in the meantime.

item.title: Transportation Dept. Threatens to Withhold Funds From N.Y. Over Noncitizen Licenses
item.description: The Trump administration gave New York 30 days to pause issuing all non-domiciled commercial driver’s licenses, among other demands, or risk losing $73 million in highway funds.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said New York’s commercial driver’s license standards represented “a systematically grossly unacceptable deviation from federal safety regulations.”

item.title: The Perfect Persimmon Cake Recipe
item.description: The juicy fruit shines when baked into a bouncy, tender batter from Eric Kim.
item.dc:creator: Eric Kim

media:content.media:credit: Nico Schinco for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Kaitlin Wayne.
media:content.media:description: Eric Kim tried many iterations of this persimmon cake before finally coming to this recipe.

item.title: Appeals Court Halts, for Now, Contempt Inquiry Into Deportation Flights
item.description: The decision from the three-judge panel served to grant the Trump administration a reprieve from having one of its top immigration lawyers have to take the witness stand next week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Justice Department’s request to the appeals court was not the first time it had sought to involve appellate judges in derailing the contempt investigation.

item.title: Make-Ahead Breakfast Ideas for Holiday Mornings
item.description: Invest in your future happiness by prepping the festive first meal of the day in advance.
item.dc:creator: Margaux Laskey

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Yossy Arefi. Prop Stylist: Marina Bevilacqua
media:content.media:description: Yossy Arefi’s sausage and mushroom strata.

item.title: At Alvin Ailey, Premieres by Jamar Roberts and Matthew Neenan
item.description: New works by Jamar Roberts and Matthew Neenan had their premieres at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert

item.title: Vote for the Best Metropolitan Diary Entry of 2025
item.description: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.
